required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Radioscapholunate Fusions After Wrist Trauma: Long-term Clinical and Radiographic Results.

brief_summary.textblock:
The investigators conduced a clinical trial to evaluate the clinical and radiographic results after radioscapholunate fusion in case of posttraumatic radiocarpal osteoarthritis.
Because of poor clinical result, many authors upgrade the procedure including excision of the distal pole of the scaphoid and later excision of the entire triquetrum.
Only one study compared the three procedures in 17 patients. The investigators performed the same comparison in 85 patients with a mean follow up of 9,1 years (1-23)

detailed_description.textblock:
The investigators compared three populations: patients with radioscapholunate (RSL) fusion alone, patients with RSLfusion and distal scaphoid excision and patient with RSL fusion, distal scaphoid excision and excision of the triquetrum.
The investigators performed clinical (pain, grasp strength, wrist motion), functional and radiographic (midcarpal osteoarthritis and radiocarpal nonunions) evaluation

primary_outcome.description: To evaluate the long-term radiographic results of post-traumatic radio scapholunate
To evaluate the long-term radiographic results of post-traumatic radio scapholunate

primary_outcome.measure: presence of non-consolidation of radio-scapho-lunar arthrodesis
primary_outcome.description: To evaluate the long-term radiographic results of post-traumatic radio scapholunate

secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate the overall survival (excluding total wrist arthrodesis) of post-traumatic radio scapholunate

secondary_outcome.measure: the prognostic factors of good clinical
secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate the prognostic factors of good clinical (ie absence of osteoarthritis or good consolidation of arthrodesis)

secondary_outcome.measure: the prognostic factors of radiographic evolution
secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate the prognostic factors of radiographic evolution (ie absence of osteoarthritis or good consolidation of arthrodesis)

study_pop.textblock: Patients who had posttraumatic radiocarpal osteoarthritis and underwent RSL fusion

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:
- posttraumatic radiocarpal osteoarthritis
- Patients who underwent radioscapholunate fusion
Exclusion criteria:
- Patients with radiocarpal osteoarthritis due to rheumatoid or inflammatory disease and Kienb√∂ck disease
- Patients with posttraumatic radiocarpal osteoarthritis managed with other surgery
